Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Mitigating Chemical Wear in Diamond Cutting Tools Using Novel Cutting Fluid Additives

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Diamond tools are ill-suited for machining ferrous alloys (e.g. steel) because of the iron-induced chemical wear of diamond. The wear mitigation techniques identified to-date have received limited industrial acceptance because they involve either extensive modifications to the machining process or compositional modifications to the ferrous alloys. This award supports fundamental research that enables the development of novel cutting fluid additives to mitigate chemical wear in diamond tools when machining ferrous alloys. The successful mitigation of this tool wear will extend the benefits of using diamond tools (namely, realizing aggressive machining conditions and generating mirror-finish surfaces) to ferrous alloys. These alloys are used widely by the multi-billion dollar manufacturing industry spanning key application sectors such as aerospace, defense, automotive, and biomedicine. Research results will also benefit the cutting fluids industry.

The research objective is to understand the influence of 2D materials on the diamond tool wear mitigation efficacy when machining ferrous alloys using colloidal suspensions of the 2D materials. The candidate 2D materials include graphene, graphene oxide, hexagonal boron nitride, molybdenum disulfide, and tungsten disulfide. Upon synthesis, the geometry of the 2D materials will be characterized using scanning electron microscopy and atomic force microscopy, whereas their chemistry will be characterized using the X-ray diffraction technique. Single point diamond turning experiments will be conducted on cylindrical ferrous workpieces. The ferrous materials of interest include iron (99.99 % purity) and steel with varying carbon concentrations, since carbon content in the alloy is known to influence the chemical wear of diamond tools. The wear mitigation efficacy of the colloidal suspensions will be quantified by measuring the volumetric tool wear (using optical profilometry), cutting temperature/forces (using in-situ sensing), carbon diffusion into the workpiece (using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy), and surface roughness (using optical profilometry).

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This research project has resulted in a chemistry-based insight into the tool wear mitigation efficacy of the candidate two-dimensional (2D) materials used to mitigate iron-induced catalytic wear. Our machining experiments with monocrystalline diamond tools show that that graphene oxide, hexagonal boron nitride, molybdenum disulfide, and tungsten disulfide are all capable of mitigating the iron-induced catalytic wear of diamond tools.  The improvements are seen to be anywhere between 38-60% over that seen using the baseline cutting fluid. Overall, graphene oxide has the most superior performance with a 60% improvement in tool wear over the baseline cutting fluid. It is followed by hexagonal boron nitride, tungsten disulfide and molybdenum disulfide that offer a 52%, 45% and 38% improvement, respectively, over the baseline case. We have also deduced the tribo-chemical pathways responsible for the tool wear performance offered by the candidate 2D materials. In addition to improved tool wear advantages, the use of these 2D materials is observed to result in the formation of chemical functional groups on the machined surface that can be leveraged for downstream applications.

On the modeling front, we have successfully developed a methodology to rank the tool wear mitigation efficacy of the candidate 2D materials. This model is predicated on the hypothesis that the complex thermo-chemical reactions governing the iron-induced catalytic wear of the diamond tool become relevant only after the platelets have effectively penetrated the iron-diamond interface.  Therefore, irrespective of the underlying reactions, the most effective platelets should be the ones that show relative ease in physically penetrating the iron-diamond interface.  Our model effectively combines density functional theory (DFT) calculations with molecular dynamics simulations to capture the effects of: (i) iron-diamond interactions; (ii) composition-dependent, pair-wise adhesion energies between the platelets and the iron/diamond surfaces; and (iii) contact stresses, sliding velocities and platelet pre-adsorption conditions relevant to machining processes. The model-predicted effective displacement values seen for each of the 2D materials correlate well with our experimental tool-wear trends  

The model results also reveal that while diamond tool wear is a complex thermo-chemical phenomenon, the adhesion energy between the 2D platelet and the iron workpiece is a strong indicator of the experimental tool wear trends. For graphene and hexagonal boron nitride, their stronger adhesion to iron results in platelet ingestion into the contact zone even at low to intermediate contact stress levels.  On the other hand, tungsten disulfide and molybdenum disulfide platelets with a ~ 40% lower adhesion energy to iron, were transported away from the contact zone, even under favorable workpiece motion conditions.  The findings suggest the possibility of using standalone DFT calculations to evaluate the tool wear mitigation efficacy of emerging 2D nanomaterials. In addition to these results, the tool-wear trends were also observed to be a function of the carbon concentration in the ferrous workpiece.

BROADER IMPACT

The successful mitigation of the iron-induced catalytic wear of diamond will extend the benefits of using diamond tools to ferrous alloys - a material class used widely by a multi-billion dollar industry spanning key application sectors such as aerospace, defense, automotive and biomedicine. The fundamental insights provided by the simulations will also benefit other processes such as, grinding, milling and lapping that involve the use of diamond tools. On the education front, the research findings have been integrated as part of multiple graduate and undergraduate courses at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, NY. It has also been incorporated into interactive outreach activities to the middle/high-school students in the upstate New York area.  In terms of human resource development, this project provided opportunities for the training and development of two student researchers (1 MS, 1 PhD) in the areas of ultraprecision machining, material characterization, and atomistic modeling. Given his expertise in diamond machining, the senior PhD student has been recruited to join Apple Inc.'s manufacturing division, starting July 2021. The project has resulted in a total of 3 peer-reviewed manuscripts and 1 PhD dissertation (all in-preparation for Spring 2021 submission).
